description: From Middle English with, from Old English wi√æ (‚Äúagainst, opposite, toward, with‚Äù), from Proto-Germanic *wi√æi, a shortened form of Proto-Germanic *wi√ærƒÖ (‚Äúagainst‚Äù). In Middle English, the word shifted to denote association rather than opposition, displacing Middle English mid (‚Äúwith‚Äù), from Old English mid (‚Äúwith‚Äù), from Proto-Germanic *midi; an earlier model of this meaning shift exists in cognate Old Norse vi√∞; elsewhere, the converse meaning shift is exposed by Old South Arabian ê©®ê©∫ê©¨‚Äé (byn, ‚Äúbetween, amid‚Äù) spawning Old South Arabian ê©®ê©¨‚Äé (bn, ‚Äúagainst‚Äù) and even likewise frequent reverse meaning ê©®ê©¨‚Äé (bn, ‚Äúfrom‚Äù).

entries.meaning: (US) Along, together with others, in a group, etc.
examples: Do you want to come with?
He picked a fight with the class bully.

entries.meaning: In the company of; alongside, close to; near to.
examples: He went with his friends.

entries.meaning: In addition to; as an accessory to.
examples: She owns a motorcycle with a sidecar.

entries.meaning: Used to add supplemental information, especially to indicate simultaneous happening, or immediate succession or consequence.
examples: Jim was listening to Bach with his eyes closed.
The match result was 10-5, with John scoring three goals.
With a heavy sigh, she looked around the empty room.
Four people were injured, with one of them in critical condition.
With their reputation on the line, they decided to fire their PR team.
We are with you all the way.
There are a number of problems with your plan.
What on Earth is wrong with my keyboard?
He was pleased with the outcome.
I'm upset with my father.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To denote the accomplishment of cause, means, instrument, etc; ‚Äì sometimes equivalent to by.
examples: slain with robbers

entries.meaning: Using as an instrument; by means of.
examples: cut with a knife
I water my plants with this watering can. This is the watering can I water my plants with.
Find what you want instantly with our search engine.
They dismissed the meeting with a wave of their hand.
Speak with a confident voice.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Using as nourishment; more recently replaced by on.

examples: It was small and bumpy, with a tinge of orange.

entries.meaning: Affected by (a certain emotion or condition).
examples: Speak with confidence.
He spoke with sadness in his voice.
The sailors were infected with malaria.
overcome with happiness
green with envy; flushed with success
She's was with Acme for twenty years before retiring last fall.

entries.meaning: Keeping up with; understanding; following along.
examples: That was a lot to explain, are you still with me?

description: From Middle English withe, wi√æ√æe, from Old English wi√æ√æe. More at withe.
